Message.Title: HTC One X+ with quad core 1.7GHz is now on sale in the US off contract and unlocked
Message.Msg: The HTC One X+ loaded with an impressive 4.7-inch Super LCD 2 screen, monster quad-core 1.7 GHz processor, 64GB internal memory and the latest Android 4.1 Jelly Bean is on sale for $699 without contract. The phone is factory unlocked and is compatible with any GSM service provider. According to the retailer’s site each order is being shipped within four days. Wanna buy the unlocked HTC One X+ cheaper? If you believe that the cost for the latest and the most powerful HTC smartphone today is too high we may have some good news for you. It is very likely that the price for the most powerful Android smartphone will drop once holiday fever and sales began. We recommend to check us on Black Friday – November 23, and Cyber Monday – November 26 when the best sales and discounts have place. Also, the price for the HTC One X+ will be corrected once the US carriers will announce availability the phone on their network. Unfortunately, none of the carriers have yet confirmed if the model will be available this year. Source: cheap-phonesDOTcom/htc-one-x-on-sale-in-the-us-off-contract-and-unlocked/

Topic.Title: HTC One X+ with quad core 1.7GHz is now on sale in the US off contract and unlocked

Message.Msg: "Unfortunately, none of the carriers have yet confirmed if the model will be available this year." Unfortunately, none of the retail cellphone buyers will have a clue it even exists unless and until their carrier decides to make it available.

Topic.Title: Forbes : Intel might buy AMD's graphics unit? Wow!

Message.Msg: In case AMD graphics unit is bought by Intel, NVDA would skyrocket because it would be the last last fish in the pond full of hungry predators.

Topic.Title: Forbes : Intel might buy AMD's graphics unit? Wow!

Message.Msg: So Best? If Intel Corporation buys AMD's graphics unit, and takes AMD's chip designs over to their brand-new 14nm fabrication facility in Chandler Arizona, -- and shrinks the AMD graphics chips down to that teeny-tiny 14 nanometers -- how will nvidia compete with that? Hummm? nvidia continues to struggle with TSMC's 28nm process -- the best they've got. While Intel would be making much speedier, more energy efficient 14nm AMD graphics chips over at their new place. Using the most advanced process technology on the planet. Take a look, boys. Google this :Update: Intel to build fab for 14-nm chips - EE Times Intel's new 14 nanometer facility in Chandler does not look like any kind of good news for nvidia. Oh no no no.

Topic.Title: Too risky holding NVDA before earnings

Message.Msg: Goes both ways -- presumably weak/low-conviction shorts should also be looking to cover going into the earnings, since there seems to be at least as much risk to the upside as the downside.

Topic.Title: Jeepers Best, Everybody else pays a dividend.

Message.Msg: So Best? Maybe the Market, she is expecting nvidia to tag along and follow Apple? And declare their First Ever Cash Dividend. Like Apple did. Now granted, nvidia can't announce a $10.60 per share dividend like Apple did. Oh no no no. That would be three times as much cash as Jen's got. But maybe a starter $00.40 dividend per nvda share? Looks to me like that's what the Market is expecting today. $00.40 dividend per nvda share. Nice, right? It sure would be. Of course, there's a down side. When the stock goes "ex-dividend", nvidia's stock price would fall right down by the amount of the dividend paid. (-$00.40) per share. Still, cause for a small celebration anyway, right?

Topic.Title: Too risky holding NVDA before earnings

Message.Msg: With every other PC parts maker coming in Well Below last year's Profit numbers, what makes you think PC parts maker nvidia will be any different? Hummm? Because nvidia is somehow "special"? Ha ha ha ha! This stock is a short's Dream Stock. It pays no dividend -- and it reports last. And 80% of their graphics chips attach to PC's. So all you need to do is watch what the other PC parts makers report, and short accordingly.

Message.Title: Best trying to create false expectation of Dividend announcement?
Message.Msg: I think I can see the twisted logic from a short/basher's point of view ... need to to find plausible way for even a great quarter to be perceived as a disappointment. Creating an unfounded rumor about a dividend announcement might do the trick, since it could theoretically create an expectation that is highly unlikely to be met. But the idea that a dividend announcement might be imminent shouldn't shouldn't make much sense to anyone that's been following the company. The last word on the company's plans for the cash position was just that they plan to make it a lot bigger. See the Q2 transcripts, available on seeking alpha. In the current phase of heavy investment, a dividend wouldn't make much sense, and I don't think any serious longs are expecting one. Making use of some of the cash to buyback some shares seems *slightly* more likely, since it would add leverage to the future earnings growth without creating an ongoing cash commitment (dividends are hard to take away) -- but such a move still seems highly unlikely based on the company's recent commentary... and the fact that the board has already has authorized and extended a buyback program through May 2013 (originating back in 2004!). See nvidiaDOTcom/object/io_1268820951326.html Committing a big chunk of cash now to a dividend (or even a buyback) would be like David pawning his slingshot in preparation for his battle with Goliath.
